87.text: family violence is actually core court business

91.text: both directly and as a backdrop to other offending.

98.text: and victims will remain at risk

104.text: The report that Rosie is launching today

109.text: turning the spotlight on the source of the problem

112.text: and bringing perpetrators of family violence squarely into view.

117.text: In doing so, it explains that far from a phenomenon

124.text: family violence consists of controlling, coercive,

129.text: abusive or violent behaviour used by identifiable individuals.

136.text: Contact with the Justice system, then,

139.text: represents an opportunity to intervene with these individuals;

142.text: an opportunity that, at this point, has not always been seized.

147.text: From the respondent churned through the court system

150.text: who does not understand the basis of a protection order;

153.text: to the man sitting on a behaviour change waiting list

159.text: from the individual jailed for a family violence assault

165.text: to the man who cannot be located by police

168.text: when an arrest needs to be made and

173.text: Too often the detached operation of the conventional court process

177.text: serves to propel perpetrators away and cement isolation

183.text: rather than keep them within reach of effective intervention.

187.text: The aim of this report is instead to write those

191.text: who commit family violence into the analysis.

194.text: In doing so, it promotes the potential of the justice system

198.text: as an active and involved participant

201.text: that can interrupt the cycle of family violence

204.text: and make those who use it more visible

209.text: by bringing him back to court to account for his commitments,

212.text: by making sure he's known to relevant service agencies

216.text: by addressing related addiction, mental health or a combination of problems

221.text: and by identifying whatever stake he may have in becoming a safer man.

227.text: It also means promoting the justice system

229.text: as a dynamic rather than static actor;

234.text: one that can adapt and tailor its responses as circumstances change,

238.text: that can be effective as early as possible

242.text: with those most likely to work towards safety

244.text: and which can be freed up to keep those posing a higher risk

252.text: The report does not suggest, of course, that these are easy solutions

256.text: or that there is just one easy solution.

259.text: The cycle of family violence is so complicated

262.text: that we cannot assume that one policy such as

266.text: the glacial road towards a National IVO Register,

269.text: for example, will make the difference.

273.text: Instead, we need a range of interventions;

276.text: ones which a perpetrator encounters repeatedly

280.text: and which reinforce over and over and over again

284.text: that his behaviour is something that we simply will not accept.

289.text: That said, the report does not call for a blunt

296.text: A lock 'em up and throw away the key approach

301.text: and certainly, imprisonment is absolutely necessary in many cases.

307.text: If this is our only response, however,

313.text: to address the violence at its source

315.text: and ensure there are not more victims down the track.

320.text: What's more, it abdicates our responsibility to acknowledge

323.text: that family violence is not something committed by

327.text: an aberrant fraction who can be pushed

331.text: but by a wide range of individuals whose behaviour

335.text: and sense of entitlement we have, collectively, allowed to endure.

340.text: Collectively, therefore, we have to develop a much smarter response

345.text: drawing on what we already know while harnassing the opportunity

349.text: that contact with the justice system presents

352.text: to step in more effectively at the earliest possible stage.

356.text: As a result, the report recommends that jurisdictions support

360.text: a dedicated conference on perpetrator interventions,

363.text: in addition to any national crisis summit currently being proposed.

367.text: It also calls for jurisdictions to develop early intervention strategies

372.text: and to fund a more considered and well-supported sector

378.text: The report also recommends the use of call-outs to police

383.text: as opportunities, not only to apply an appropriate criminal or civil justice response,

389.text: but also to make referrals to a range of other services.

394.text: In particular, the report highlights a need

396.text: for perpetrators to be referred to crisis accommodation

400.text: so that they do not spiral into isolation

403.text: and instead are kept within view.

406.text: It also calls for perpetrators to be connected to an active men’s referral service

414.text: support speedier inter-agency collaboration and ongoing contact

418.text: with perpetrators prior to a court appearance.

422.text: Once a perpetrator has contact with the court,

425.text: the report suggests ways in which this interaction can become much more powerful,

430.text: harnessing the potential of a court appearance to connect perpetrators

434.text: to early referral and treatment including those who may have used family violence

439.text: but are actually charged with other offences;

442.text: using bail and remand as an opportunity to do the same;

447.text: recognising the value of appropriately trained respondent workers

451.text: and duty lawyers in protection order hearings;

453.text: using the imprimatur of a judge’s authority to increase a perpetrator’s willingness to comply with orders,

461.text: applying swift and reliable sanctions and bringing perpetrators back

467.text: for ongoing monitoring and assessment before the court.

471.text: The report, then, recommends ways in which the correction system can be used more effectively.

476.text: To monitor offenders whilst they’re in the community,

478.text: to intervene in rather than perpetuate the cycle of violence in custodial settings,

484.text: to use these settings to screen for and identify

488.text: family violence perpetration in the general population of offenders

492.text: and to explore possibilities for ongoing monitoring post-release.

498.text: Importantly, the report calls on jurisdictions to interrupt the transmission of family violence between generations

505.text: by responding more effectively to adolescents who use violence in the home

510.text: as well as to children at risk of the profound harm that we know that exposure to family violence can cause.

517.text: Overall, these recommendations are about removing the burden from victims of family violence

524.text: and placing that burden squarely on the system.

529.text: Just as urgently, therefore, the report calls for us to face up to our own accountability

535.text: as individuals, as jurisdictions, and as a population at large.

540.text: Family violence is quite simply the greatest threat to our collective wellbeing.

548.text: If we’re serious about tackling this threat head on therefore,

551.text: we need to be prepared to commit to more and targeted resources for support services,

558.text: first and foremost, but also for additional interventions right along the spectrum

564.text: which may ultimately see these services experience less demand.

568.text: After all, we know enough about the costs of family violence to realise that

574.text: simply doing more of the same is not going to stem its ongoing drain on our social and economic future.

583.text: What’s more, and as an example in this report highlights,

587.text: interventions which prevent even one family violence related homicide

597.text: Substantial though the challenge might be, therefore,

600.text: and as entrenched as patterns of violence are in many of those who use it,

604.text: understanding of the cause of family violence and the

607.text: attitudes which support it has reached a crucial stage,

611.text: as has the community’s motivation to do something about it.

614.text: As Rosie herself has emphasised, our overall focus needs to shift

620.text: from simply expecting a victim to keep herself safe, to leave, to report breaches, to testify;

628.text: to demanding the perpetrators take responsibility for their violence and an effective intervention is applied.

635.text: Equally, our focus needs to shift from

638.text: hoping that the law will address a single incident to

642.text: ensuring that repeated interventions might also

646.text: break the cycle of violence for subsequent generations.

650.text: As a former politician, I know they certainly spend a great deal of time

655.text: talking about valuing families as well as about securing our social and economic future.

662.text: Addressing the violence occurring within these families then, is a crucial way of doing both.

670.text: This report explains there are things that we can do now to mount a more

675.text: comprehensive and proactive response to family violence.

679.text: Its aim is to show that if we widen our gaze, we can make a start,

685.text: broadening the conversation, seizing opportunities, stepping in earlier

690.text: and bringing perpetrators of family violence clearly, unequivocally, into view.

1219.text: Having been asked to investigate early interventions in the justice system

1223.text: and having decided to focus on family violence, what struck us, in particular, about it

1228.text: was the way in which the justice sector kept sending Greg away,

1231.text: bouncing him off the system, entrenching isolation and distorted thinking;

1236.text: in short, leaving it until things were too late rather than stepping in early to intervene.

1241.text: In many ways, then, Rosie’s story crystallised the focus of this report

1246.text: and we are incredibly grateful for her generosity,

1249.text: not only in meeting with us early in its development, but of course for her presence here today.

1253.text: We’re also very grateful, however, for the input of so many others in the sector

1258.text: which I think is, perhaps, the report’s greatest value.

1261.text: When we first asked stakeholders to participate we were very conscious that

1265.text: potentially, here was yet another report into family violence,

1269.text: a subject that was and still is attracting a great deal of attention

1272.text: and demanding a great deal of professional time.

1276.text: A large volume of work already exists that describes the deficiencies of the legal system,

1281.text: all of which needed to be reviewed, of course, in order to understand the challenge.

1285.text: Just another research project, however, could easily end up on the shelf,

1289.text: something that we at the Centre for Innovative Justice are loathe to see occur. (Audience chuckling)

1293.text: Instead, and thankfully, we encountered incredible openness from the sector with both their time and ideas;

1300.text: many spending considerable hours talking about their experiences

1304.text: and their thoughts for the direction in which efforts should head.

1306.text: In particular, and though unfortunately he couldn’t be here today,

1310.text: Rodney Vlais from No to Violence was a source of great knowledge and possibility

1313.text: pointing us in a range of directions but never prescribing the end result and I really want to thank him.

1319.text: More broadly, we were fortunate to speak with a wide range of professionals interstate and internationally.

1325.text: We spoke to behaviour change practitioners, policy officers, magistrates,

1329.text: court staff, lawyers, academics and, of course, women’s support services

1334.text: and our hope is that this report highlights in some small way the amazing work

1338.text: that all of these people are doing and their determination to keep women and children safe.

1344.text: Another hope is that this report demonstrates that the same themes

1348.text: emerged time and time again throughout all these consultations.

1351.text: Just one of them was that perpetrator accountability

1354.text: is a complex concept and means more than just one thing.

1359.text: First and foremost, of course, those consulted told us

1362.text: that accountability means making victims of family violence safe.

1366.text: Beyond this, it means keeping the perpetrator firmly in view,

1370.text: not isolating him or propelling him from scrutiny.

1372.text: It means leveraging the authority of the justice system and whatever stake

1376.text: in conformity a man has to ensure that he complies with orders.

1380.text: It means measuring the right things.

1382.text: It means keeping not only the violence and its user visible but also the system’s response.

1387.text: It means every part of the system bearing responsibility

1391.text: and the victim setting the pace.

1393.text: Just as importantly, it means coming to terms with the fact that family violence

1396.text: is core business in the legal system and has to be treated and funded as such.

1402.text: A further theme was that although perpetrators of family violence often exhibit similar traits

1407.text: they are still individuals with whom the justice system can and must intervene.

1411.text: What’s more, different interventions will be more or less successful with some than with others.

1416.text: For that reason, while we continue to use the terms perpetrators for reasons of consistency with the National Plan,

1422.text: we’ve also attempted to use language that writes men back into an unapologetically gendered analysis.

1429.text: Language that unpacks the homogeneous descriptions which we believe

1432.text: have perpetuated the system’s failures for both women and men alike.

1437.text: A final theme to emerge from our consultations was that there was obviously no magic solution,

1442.text: no quirky initiative as one sage cautioned upon which we could stumble and hold triumphantly to the sky.

1448.text: This was never the ambition of this report.

1451.text: Those who have been working in this field for decades or have lived with family violence, even for a day,

1456.text: know that it is far too complex to be met with just one response.

1460.text: Instead, the more modest ambition for this report was to reflect a certain level of consensus,

1465.text: to highlight opportunities, to synthesise ideas and

1469.text: to do so in language which might enable them to be taken up down the track.

1473.text: Many in the field have been saying it for a long time, the National Plan says it too,

1477.text: we have to talk more openly about perpetrator accountability and

1481.text: our hope for this report is that it provides a platform for this conversation to occur. Thank you. (Applause)
